note.p: John Gill Shorter was governor of Alabama during the first half of the Civil War.

Born on April 23, 1818, in Monticello, Georgia, Shorter graduated from the University of Georgia in 1837 and then moved to Alabama, where his family had settled a few years earlier. The Shorters gradually purchased land in Barbour County, Alabama, becoming one of the wealthiest families in the area. Shorter became a practicing attorney and opened a successful law firm with a brother in Alabama.

In the early 1840s, Shorter became active in Democratic politics and in 1845 won a seat in the Alabama Senate. He served a single term, and then won a seat in the Alabama House of Representatives in 1851. However, he left the House before the end of his term when he received an appointment as circuit judge. He served as a judge through the 1850s, but continued to be involved in politics. Like most other southern leaders of the time, Shorter was strongly pro-slavery, advocating the institution’s expansion westward. He initially was not a vocal proponent of secession, but supported financial policies that boosted the south’s independence from the northern economy.

When Abraham Lincoln won the presidential election in 1860, Shorter endorsed secession. The governor of Alabama, Andrew B. Moore, appointed Shorter a secession commissioner to Georgia, tasked with recruiting that state to secede and join a southern confederacy. He then won a seat in the Provisional Confederate Congress and helped write a constitution for the Confederate States of America. In August 1861, Shorter successfully ran for governor Alabama. Although he had long advocated states’ rights, the realities of war against a larger, more powerful Union led Shorter to adopt policies that countered his pre-war principles. He supported the Confederate government’s military draft, and he urged the Alabama legislature to pass a law that allowed him to impress slaves, from Alabama slaveowners, to work on state and military projects. These policies and other wartime events outraged many southerners, and resulted in Shorter’s popularity sharply declining while in office. He lost reelection in 1863.

After the expiration of his term, Shorter returned to his home in Eufaula, Alabama, and practiced law until he died on May 29, 1872. He was married to Mary Jane Battle. Shorter is buried in Shorter Cemetery in Eufala, Alabama.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Encyclopedia of Alabama)

note.p: Thomas Hill Watts, Sr., was the governor of Alabama during the second half of the Civil War.

Born on January 3, 1819, near Pine Flat, Alabama, Watts graduated from the University of Virginia, studied law, and became a practice attorney in Greenville, Alabama, by 1841. He relocated to Montgomery in 1848, where his law firm thrived. Aside from his legal practice, Watts received a large amount of money as a planter, owning a large amount of land and more than 175 slaves.

Watts was a Unionist during the growing sectional conflict over slavery in the 1850s. However, following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the president in November 1860, Watts joined the call for secession. He served as a delegate at the Alabama secession convention, and was among the officials who signed the ordinance of secession in January 1861. Following an unsuccessful bid for governor of Alabama in 1861, Watts raised the Seventeenth Alabama Infantry Regiment and briefly commanded it as colonel. However, he resigned in 1862 when offered the position as attorney general of the Confederacy by President Jefferson Davis. In that role, Watts helped create the Confederate Supreme Court and defended the Confederacy’s Conscription Act of 1862 which was the first draft law in North America.

In 1863, Watts resigned from the attorney general’s position to run for governor of Alabama again. He won against the incumbent, John Gill Shorter, in part due to his more nationalistic views of the Confederacy, which proved popular among many Alabama citizens who were frustrated with Shorter’s handling of state matters. He battled currency inflation issues and faced an anti-war movement in the Alabama legislature in 1864. Overall, his term in office was filled with internal strife as Union forces campaigned across the south and Confederate armies disintegrated from casualties, defeats, and desertions. He was arrested by Union officials on May 1, 1865, and spent a few weeks in prison before being paroled.

Union forces had destroyed much of Watts’ plantation and liberated his slaves during the war. He sold a great deal of his plantation to pay debts, and returned to practicing law in Montgomery. He remained active in Democratic politics and worked against Republican Reconstruction, although he did not hold major political office again.

Watts died on September 16, 1892. He was married twice, first to Eliza Brown Allen, who passed away in 1873. He then married Eleanor Clark Noyes in 1875. Watts had a total of eleven children. He is buried in Oakwood Cemetery in Montgomery, Alabama.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Encyclopedia of Alabama)

note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

Currently located in Lowndes County, Columbus was founded on December 6, 1819 in what was then a "non-county area." When Lowndes County was created on January 30, 1830, Columbus became its county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Elmore County, Alabama, Wetumpka was founded as early as 1714. Previously located in Mississippi Territory, it was merged into Alabama Territory on March 2, 1817 in Montgomery County. When Elmore County was created on December 30, 1866, it became its county seat. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Montgomery County, Montgomery was founded in 1819 and serves as the county seat and state capital. (Encyclopedia of Alabama)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

gloss.p: When the 13th Amendment abolished slavery, it failed to abolish involuntary servitude. The amendment included a loophole banning involuntary servitude "except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted" (Library of Congress). White southerners in the post-emancipation South, concerned about both the availability of labor and the freedom of African Americans, manipulated this clause and turned to convict leasing to entrench long standing racial hierarchies.

Immediately after the war, many states passed "Black Codes" or laws severely limiting African Americans' rights. Under these codes and other similar laws passed in the decades following the Civil War, African Americans could be arrested for any number of petty crimes, including vagrancy (functionally construed to mean any act of social mobility not approved by a white person) or theft (in Mississippi a felony if exceeding $10 worth of goods). Widespread racism and stereotypes about Black criminality led to a dramatic expansion in the population of imprisoned individuals and an overwhelming number of African Americans within that population. Many states leased those convicted persons to private companies or individuals for their labor, and in certain cases lessees had been the pre-emancipation enslaver of the leased.

Laborers worked in a variety of settings including shipbuilding and timber cutting, yet the most prominent form in states like Mississippi remained large-scale agricultural work. The convict lease system was incredibly dangerous and difficult for those who lived through it, as leased persons faced unsafe working conditions, inadequate living conditions, abuse from lessees, and grueling work schedules. Given these circumstances, the ready availability of imprisoned laborers, and the callousness of lessees and state officials, the mortality rate among convict laborers was incredibly high.

Certain states ceased leasing imprisoned persons to individuals or private companies in the late nineteenth century, only to continue using that labor on state-funded infrastructure projects like road or highway construction until, in some cases, World War II. Southern individuals and states thereby continued to increase their wealth through the coerced labor of African Americans while perpetuating anti-Black racism and laying the foundations of the modern prison-industrial complex (Library of Congress; Mississippi Encyclopedia).

Like many slaveholding states of the former Confederacy, Alabama operated a convict leasing system between 1875–1928. Under convict leasing systems, states leased imprisoned people to perform unfree labor for companies and individuals in exchange for a fee. State and county laws and racially selective prosecutions funneled large, overrepresented populations of African Americans into the prison system, and in Alabama African Americans comprised more than 95% of the county and 90% of the state's prison population. Therefore, Alabama's convict leasing system replaced the state's former system of race-based chattel slavery and laborers encountered harsh conditions, violent punishments, and high death tolls. Those who were not leased (and all imprisoned women after 1888) were imprisoned in the Alabama State Penitentiary in Wetumpka in Elmore County. (Encyclopedia of Alabama)

In the wake of the Civil War, many states turned to convict leasing to bolster infrastructural repair and to maintain long standing racial hierarchies. Like many other southern states, Mississippi instituted a convict leasing program, and in 1876 the state passed the Leasing Act (commonly known as the “Pig Law”), which sentenced anyone who stole property valued at $10 or greater up to five years in prison and quadrupled the prison population, with Black prisoners comprising approximately 85% of inmates. The state most frequently leased convicted persons to individuals, primarily to perform agricultural work on cotton farms.

However, the state also leased incarcerated persons to private companies, such as the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad Company, and companies subjected convict-laborers to excruciating working conditions with little shelter, sustenance, or medical care. While companies and private individuals leased enslaved workers during the antebellum era, enslavers expected “their human chattel to be returned alive and in good working condition” (Sturkey, Hattiesburg). However, this expectation was virtually nonexistent in postwar convict leasing programs. The death toll therefore grew to staggering heights. In response, Mississippi cancelled Gulf & Ship Island’s contract in December 1888 and ceased leasing convicts to private companies in 1890. However, the state and individual counties and towns continued to use convict labor for public works projects and at the state’s penitentiary at Parchman plantation well into the twentieth century (Mississippi Encyclopedia).

Like many slaveholding states of the former Confederacy, Mississippi operated a convict leasing system between the 1860s–1900s. Under convict leasing systems, states leased imprisoned people to perform unfree labor for companies and individuals in exchange for a fee. State and county laws (such as "Pig Laws" and vagrancy laws) and racially selective prosecutions funneled large, overrepresented populations of African Americans into their prison institutions. Therefore, Mississippi's convict leasing system replaced the state's former system of race-based chattel slavery and laborers encountered harsh conditions, violent punishments, and high death tolls. Public outcry over these conditions, especially following the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad Company's convict leasing practices, forced Mississippi to abolish its convict leasing program in 1890, becoming the first state to do so. County governments, however, continued to operate convict leasing arrangements using chain gangs until the 1900s. In 1904 Mississippi opened Parchman Prison on a cotton plantation in the Mississippi Delta and consolidated much of its convict labor there. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A legal order that states that a person in prison must appear before and be judged by a court of law before he or she can be forced by law to stay in prison." (Cambridge Dictionary)

While the Alabama Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. Bills are originated in either house, and to become law, must receive a simple majority in both chambers. Once passed, it is sent to the Alabama state governor for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and the state legislature can overcome the veto with a two-third majority. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Alabama State Penitentiary (also known as the Wetumpka State Penitentiary) was built in Wetumpka, Coosa County, Alabama in 1841. It was the state’s first prison and formally authorized by an act of the state legislature on January 26, 1839. In 1922 it was converted to exclusively house female prisoners until 1942 and was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1973. The remaining structures were demolished by the end of the twentieth century. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A building where criminals are forced to live as a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Operating at the state level, the Alabama Executive Department was established by Article IV of the Alabama Constitution (1819) on July 5, 1819 and is headed by the Office of the Governor. All agencies and offices within the Department are subordinate to the Governor. The Alabama Executive Department consists of a governor, lieutenant governor, attorney-general, state auditor, secretary of state, state treasurer, commissioner of agriculture and industries, and a sheriff for each county. (Avalon Project-Alabama: Constitution of 1819; Alabama Department of Archives & History)

Operating at the state level, the Alabama State Legislature (also known as the General Assembly) was established by Article III of the Alabama Constitution (1819) on July 5, 1819. It is a bicameral body, divided into the upper house (State Senate) and the Lower House (State House of Representatives) and is responsible for making and amending the laws of the state. (Alabama Department of Archives & History; Avalon Project-Alabama: Constitution of 1819; Wikipedia)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

"Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Clark Collection. Letter from M. G. Moore, the warden of the Alabama Penitentiary at Wetumpka, Alabama, to Alabama Governor Thomas H. Watts, reporting on the prisoners from Mississippi whom the Alabama Penitentiary is temporarily holding. Then-Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus ordered that these prisoners be transferred from the Mississippi State Penitentiary to Alabama in 1863 through an agreement with then-Alabama Governor John G. Shorter. M. G. Moore's letter consists of handwritten copies of correspondence between Pettus, Shorter, Moore, and the Alabama Penitentiary board of inspectors regarding the transfer of the Mississippi prisoners as well as questions about the legality of Shorter's right to accept the prisoners and whether they can require the prisoners to perform labor. Moore intersperses brief explanations about these circumstances and his own actions throughout the letter. Appended to the letter is a receipt for prisoner-related expenses.

div.p: [seal]

His Execellency
Thomas H Watts
Montgomery Ala
Dr Sir
Below you will find the correspondence and orders in reference to the Mississippi prisoners in this prison
"Executive Department"
Montgomery Ala May 4th 1863

Dr M G Moore
Warden Ala Penitentiary
Dear Sir
I recieved yesterday from Gov Pettus of Mississippi a dispatch which the following is a copy
"Jackson May 2d 1863

Twenty three (23) convicts in Mississippi penitentiary disloyal and dangerous men. Will you receive them temporaly in your penitentiary? In case of neecessity I am sending them under guard. Answer by telegraph John J Pettus" to which I replied—"Send your convicts here under guard I will receive them"

I regret that this application was made, but I could not refuse it in view of the present condition of affairs in Mississippi—You will have to make needful provision at once for their safe keeping and Maintaince. They will probaly arrive in a few days.

(Signed) Respectfully
Your Obt Svt
Jno Gill Shorter"

After receipt of the letters I went to Mongtomery and saw Gov Shorter in person in reference to these prisoners and his instruction to me was under all the circumstances and as their stay needs only be temporary to keep them in Isolatory Confinement as it would mean less risk and expense in extra guards. On the 8th May 1863 I made the following order

Executive Department
Montgomery Ala May 8 1863

Drct M G Moore
Warden of the Penitentiary
Wetumpka Ala
Sir
This will be handed you by Mr J M Rice

who is in charge of the prisoners sent by Gov Pettus for safe keeping in our Penitentiary and of whom you have been advised. You will please give Mr Rice the necessary necessary receipt for these prisoners as turned over to you
Very Respectfully

(Signed) [gap] Jno Gill Shorter
Gov of Alabama

The boards of inspection are of the opinion that we had no right to work them or control them whatever. In fact no jurisdiction over them at all. Upon investigation I found there was no Mechanics amongst them as they had been Cotton factory hands.

We tried and could not find emp-loyment for all of our own prisoners owing to the want and difficiency of getting Material and we did not think it would be profitable to undertake to make Mechanics out of them and let men of ours be idle even had the boards of inspectors thought we had jurisdiction over them

I had frequent payment [enclosed?] with Gov Shorter in reference to them and he said we would have to do the best we could under the circumstances he could not insist upon their being removed and it was from my representive that he sent a message to Gov
Pettus of their condition &c which caused Gov Pettus to write the following letter—

"Executive Department
Columbus Miss 4 Nov 1863

Hon John Gill Shorter
Governor of Alabama
Governor
Your message was delivered by Mr Brown.

You will please immediately have the Convicts sent by me to your State Penitentiary put to work and treated exactly as your other convicts. I was surprised to learn that they have remained idle so long, for when I sent them I supposed it was understood they were to be placed on the same footing as Convicts belonging to your State

I am Governor
(Signed) [gap] Your Obt Servt
John J Pettus "

"Executive Department
Montgomery Aug 11 1863

Dr Mr G Moore
Warden Ala Penitentiary
Wetumpka Ala
Sir, [gap] I enclose you a copy of a letter received from his Excellency John J Pettus Governor of the State of Mississippi in which he request that the Convicts
in the Ala Penitentary should be "put to work and treated exactly as your own convicts". As far as you can conveniently comply with this request of Gov Pettus I hope you will.

Respectfully
Your Obt Svt

(signed) [gap] Jno Gill Shorter
Gov of Alabama
On receipt of this letter from Gov Shorter I addressed the following to the Inspectors.

Ala Penitentary
Wetumpka [Nov?] 14th 1864

Inspectors Ala Penitentary
Gentlemen

Enclosed you will find copies of letters from Govs Pettus and Shorter in regards to the working of the Mississippi prisoners. As there is some doubt of the legality and propriety of working them I do not feel authorized to take the responsibility upon myself without some action of the boards of Inspectors and ask you to take some action upon this subject as soon as practible

Very Respectfully
(signed) [gap] Your Obt Svt
M G Moore Warden
The inspectors did not take any action at this time but addressed your Excellency upon the subject giving you their views and all the particulars in relation to them and the following is your reply—

Executive Department of Ala
Montgomery Dec 31st 1863

Messers M G Moore Warden &c
Thomas Williams
L P Saxon &
A C Baker
Inspectors of Alabama Penitentary
Gentlemen

I have your letter of the 24 ' inst in reference to the Mississippi Convicts received into the Penitentary last May. Whatever doubts may have existed as to the right of the executive of Ala to recev said prisoners or as to the right of the State Officers of Ala to put them to work in our penitentary, have been remand by the act of the Legislation of this State passed on the 29th of August 1863 and found on pages 33 & 34 of Acts of Extra Session in August.
So long as the present Condition of Mississippi remains it would be an act of discourtersy to a sister State to refuse
to keep prisoners if we have the room in our institutions. If consistent with safety such convicts ought to be worked and treated in all respects as if they were convicts sentenced by our Courts—
In my opinion a writ of habeas corpus I need out by these [puds?] of these Courts will avail them nothing.
I desire that they should be put to work and treated as Convicts under sentence from our own Courts
Very Respectfully

(signed) [gap] T H Watts
Gov of Ala
At a regular meeting of the board of Inspectors on the 6th Feb 1864 the following order was issued that
"The Mississippi convicts are allowed the privledge of the cell room for exercise during the day under a special guard and to be employed at any useflu labor the Warden can find for them to do."

Thos Williams
(signed) [gap] A C Baker
Lyd P Saxon

As to working them in the cell rooms in here no work that cou d be done in it. For the last two years it has been impossible to find employment for ^all^ our prisoners owing to the great difficulty (and in many respects impossible) to get such material as we could manufacture and we are now doing scarcely any thing except for the goverment and such work as they furnish the material for.

The amended bill against the State ^of Miss^ is made from the actual cost of [provisions?] and clothing and no charge for the [work?] and in the future we will have to be governed by the price as it may increase or [demand?]decline. At the present price of meat &c two ($200) dollars per day will barely pay for it.
Trusting that under the circumstances this explanation will be satisfactory to your excellency I am
Your Obt Sert

M G Moore
Warden
